title: For the Leclercs, only the name is inherited
summary: 'Successions,' season 3 (2/6). Edouard Leclerc, founder of the Leclerc cooperative that became a global retailer, had planned to choose his successor among its members, but his son Michel-Edouard stepped into the shoes. At 72, 'France's favorite CEO' is in no hurry to hand over the reins to his own successor.

title: French left torn after Mélenchon threatens procedure to remove Macron from office
summary: On Sunday, the Socialists, Greens and Communists distanced themselves from the 'solemn warning' issued to President Macron by La France Insoumise leader Jean-Luc Mélenchon, fearing the threat scuttles the left's chances of governing.

title: Why Macron is (still) in no hurry to name a prime minister
summary: The appointment of a new prime minister will take place next week, after Emmanuel Macron consults with party leaders this Thursday. The president is taking his time to push back the specter of his imminent disappearance.

title: Netanyahu agreed to US proposal to bridge gap in Gaza ceasefire talks, Blinken says
summary: In a video statement released by his office after meeting Blinken, the Israeli PM said he sought to free a 'maximum number' of living hostages held in Gaza in the first stage of a proposed ceasefire deal.

title: Fear among Birmingham's Muslims after racist riots
summary: In the UK's second-largest city, home to its largest Muslim community outside London, the fear is palpable and the city's mosques have issued advice to their faithful, including not to pay attention to rumors.

title: Michel Guérard, chef who was last living legend of 'nouvelle cuisine,' has died
summary: A three-Michelin-star chef since 1977 at the hotel-restaurant Les Prés d'Eugénie, combining slimming cuisine with gourmandise, Guérard died on Sunday at age 91.

title: Trump shares fake AI images claiming support from Taylor Swift and fans
summary: The Republican presidential nominee shared doctored images on social media suggesting that the pop star and her fans support his campaign.

title: In Moscow, fear of a new military call-up: 'Our borders are not being protected'
summary: The war in the Kursk region is arousing mixed feelings among men of fighting age, as sign-up bounties reach record sums.

title: Japan to start trial removal of nuclear debris from Fukushima reactor
summary: The operator of the tsunami-hit nuclear plant aims to retrieve a tiny sample of the radioactive debris inside reactors for study, a step towards decommissioning the plant.

title: Bangladesh war crimes tribunal probes cases against ousted PM Hasina
summary: The tribunal has launched three 'mass murder' probes into its founder Sheikh Hasina, the ousted premier who fled the country due to anti-government protests.

title: Protests widen over Indian doctor's rape and murder
summary: Doctors in government-run hospitals went on strike across the country, while rival football fans marched together in support.

title: The left is being tested by the Venezuelan crisis
summary: In Latin America, a division between democracies and authoritarian regimes seems to have replaced the traditional left-right divide after Nicolas Maduro's self-proclaimed victory in the presidential election.

title: Thierry Henry steps down as coach of France's U-21s
summary: The former international, who took the job in the summer of 2023, took this decision for 'personal reasons,' said the French Football Federation. A few days ago, he won silver with the Olympic squad.

title: Ukrainian forces claim to hold Russian soldiers captured in Kursk region
summary: Moscow has reportedly contacted Kyiv to initiate talks about a prisoner exchange. Eleven days after the start of its offensive on Russian territory, Ukraine continues to apply pressure to the Kremlin.

title: 'French monument': Film world and politicians pay tribute to Alain Delon
summary: The actor's death on Sunday, August 18, at the age of 88 prompted a wave of reactions, from Emmanuel Macron to Brigitte Bardot.

title: Italy salutes Alain Delon, the French actor who is part of Italian history
summary: The tributes came in quickly in Italy on Sunday following the death of the actor known for 'The Leopard,' 'L'Eclisse,' 'Rocco and His Brothers' and 'La prima notte di quiete' – all filmed with Italian directors.

title: Five French coastal gardens to visit this summer
summary: Gardens along the Atlantic and Mediterranean coasts often feature exotic plants that thrive in the local climate, and thanks to plentiful spring rains, they are a joy to stroll through in the summer season.

title: How Bilbao's Guggenheim Museum is reinvigorating the region's economy
summary: The economic impact generated since the Guggenheim opened in 1996 is estimated at €7.7 billion, and the museum contributes 10 times more to the Basque treasury than the public funds it receives.

title: Mpox cases on the rise in DR Congo as nations pledge vaccines
summary: More than 3.5 million doses of mpox vaccines have been pledged to the Democratic Republic of Congo as it continues to see an increase in the spread of mpox.

title: German local elections are threatening aid to Ukraine
summary: The government is considering reducing its financial aid to Kyiv, while in three eastern Länder, where elections are scheduled for September, the far right and the radical left, both in favor of halting arms deliveries to Ukraine, are gaining momentum.

title: Mike Lynch, controversial British tech magnate, missing after shipwreck in Italy
summary: His yacht sank in a storm off Sicily. Long accused of accounting fraud, the 'British Bill Gates' had just won a trial in the US after a long legal battle with Hewlett-Packard.

title: UN denounces 'unacceptable' violence against aid workers, record number killed in 2023
summary: The organization warns the war in Gaza could cause another unprecedented number of aid workers to be killed this year.

title: North Korea, suffering from climate change and from its own refusal of foreign aid, is threatened by food shortages
summary: Flooding at the end of July and fears of further rain and above-average temperatures are threatening agricultural production in this country, which is reluctant to accept any outside help, particularly from its enemy to the south.

title: Channel crossings are becoming increasingly deadly for migrants
summary: Twenty-five people have perished at sea since the start of the year, more than in 2023 and 2022. Many died of asphyxiation in overcrowded dinghies.

title: Kamala Harris makes surprise appearance at DNC as party says goodbye to Biden
summary: On the first night of the Democratic National Convention in Chicago, the vice president thanked Biden for his leadership, adding that the country is 'forever grateful'.

title: Kylian Mbappé counterattacks to reclaim unpaid sums from PSG
summary: Le Monde has learned the Real Madrid player, who is claiming nearly €55 million gross from his former club, has referred the matter to the legal committee of the French Professional Football League, as well as to UEFA, via the French Football Federation.

title: Hundreds of firefighters deployed in southern France to tackle three fires
summary: The 600 firefighters managed to contain a blaze that ravaged 350 hectares in the southern Hérault department. A campground was evacuated in the Pyrénées-Orientales department.

title: The top music festivals in France between now and the end of August
summary: From jazz in Nice to world music on Tatihou Island, here's Le Monde's pick of the best summer music festivals to enjoy all over France this August.

title: In Switzerland, a bombshell report to call for adapting neutrality by moving closer to NATO
summary: A working paper commissioned by the Swiss Defense Ministry encourages the Swiss Confederation to collaborate more actively with NATO's security framework. In particular, it advocates the participation of Swiss soldiers in joint Alliance maneuvers.

title: Australia and Indonesia unveil new defense pact
summary: Indonesia explained the need for Australian help in areas like agriculture and drug trafficking.

title: Occupied Palestinian 'territories' or 'territory'? ICJ insists on singular
summary: The UN's top court says there is a fundamental unity of all the Palestinian territories occupied by Israel, whether East Jerusalem, the West Bank or the Gaza Strip.

title: Democratic convention opens with Biden's farewell: 'I love the job, but I love my country more'
summary: The Democratic convention that will make Vice President Harris's candidacy official runs until Thursday. Monday night's speakers included Hillary Clinton, who declared that 'something is happening in America – you can feel it.'

title: Israel army says it retrieved bodies of six hostages from Gaza
summary: The hostages were Yagev Buchshtab, Alexander Dancyg, Yoram Metzger, Nadav Popplewell, Chaim Perry, previously announced dead, and Avraham Munder.

title: Morocco's king pardons more than 4,800 cannabis farmers
summary: The world's leading cannabis producer has pardoned farmers accused of illegally growing the crop as the country positions itself on the global market for legal cannabis.

title: US regulators order inspections of pilot seats on Boeing 787 planes
summary: The FAA said they ordered inspections of pilot seats on hundreds of Boeing 787 planes after a March flight in which the plane's sudden plunge led to passenger injuries.

title: After Tel Aviv bombing, Hamas and Palestinian Islamic Jihad threaten further attacks in Israel
summary: The claim of a powerful explosion on Sunday raised the specter of suicide bombings, while numerous attacks have been committed on Israel's territory since the massacre on October 7, 2023.

title: Majestic photos of last night's supermoon
summary: The supermoon, which is nothing more than a full moon at the point of orbit closest to the Earth, could be admired from several points around the world in the night sky of August 19-20.

title: Former Nazi camp secretary loses appeal against conviction for complicity in murder
summary: Irmgard Furchner, 97, was handed a two-year suspended sentence in December 2022 for her role in the murder of prisoners at the Stutthof camp in occupied Poland.

title: EU plans 36% tariff on Chinese EVs, with lower duty for Tesla
summary: The European Commission said Tuesday it plans to slap five-year import duties on Chinese electric cars, unless Beijing can offer an alternative solution to the trade row over state subsidies.

title: World's oldest person, Spain's Maria Branyas, dies at age 117
summary: Branyas lived through the 1918 flu, World War I and II, Spain's civil war, and the Covid-19 pandemic. She lived for the last two decades in the Santa Maria del Tura nursing home in the town of Olot, Spain.

title: India's Supreme Court orders task force after protests over doctor's rape and murder
summary: In response to a week of furious protests, India's top court has ordered a task force to examine how to increase security for medical workers after the rape and murder of a doctor in Kolkata.

title: Quebec-based Couche-Tard stakes big in bid to acquire 7-Eleven convenience stores
summary: On August 19, the Canadian convenience store chain submitted a friendly offer to buy Japanese Seven & I Holdings, owner of 7-Eleven stores, with a view to creating a global giant.

title: French interior minister says 25,000 police will guard the Paralympic Games
summary: Gérald Darmanin reiterated that authorities have detected no 'tangible' terror threat to the Paralympics, which will be held from August 28 to September 8 in Paris and nearby sites.

title: 'The risk of China canceling out the benefits of international trade is worrying'
summary: Economist Laurent Augier recalls that a 2004 article by Nobel Prize-winning economist Paul Samuelson anticipated a situation in which the theory of comparative advantages, the 'doxa' of globalization, would no longer apply.

title: Ukraine MPs vote to ban Russia-linked Orthodox Church
summary: Kyiv has been trying to curb spiritual ties with Russia for years – a process that was accelerated by Moscow's 2022 invasion, which the powerful Russian Orthodox Church endorsed.

title: In the Saadé family, there is no boundary between business and private life
summary: 'Successions,' season 3 (3/6). Rodolphe Saadé succeeded his father Jacques at the helm of CMA CGM in 2017, a year before his death. The heir is now preparing the third generation to run the family business, today a shipping, logistics and media giant.

title: Afghan refugees in Iran targeted by deportation campaign
summary: Some 20 online petitions are calling for the deportation of Afghan nationals to their neighboring country. The movement, orchestrated on social media, has the tacit support of the authorities.
